awd_titl_txt: Research Initiation Award: Investigation on Tribo-charging Behavior of Agricultural Particles in the Development of Water-free Bio-separation Approach for Biomass Residues
awd_abstract_narration:
Research Initiation Awards provide support for junior and mid-career faculty at Historically Black Colleges and Universities who are building new research programs or redirecting and rebuilding existing programs. It is expected that the award helps to further the faculty member's research capability and effectiveness, improves research and teaching at the home institution, and involves undergraduate students in research experiences. The project seeks to develop a new method of separating agriculture biomass residues based on their electrostatic properties rather than size and density. 

Conventional wet processes to the purification of protein-rich biomass residues require large amounts of water and energy and the native functionality of the proteins is lost due to pH changes and temperature effects required for dehydration. This project will employ a tribo-electrostatic technique to pneumatically transfer milled agricultural residues into a fluidized bed reservoir where protein and fiber particles in the flour will be charged to different levels through collisions with the wall of the bed and/or interparticle contact, before being separated under the influence of an electric field. The long-term research goals are to expand the application of tribo-electrostatic separation (TES) technology to fractionate lignocellulosic biomass residues to further evaluate their tribo-charging behavior and to investigate the quality of the produced fractions for biofuel production. Moreover, these principles can be potentially used for food powder coating as well as coating solid pharmaceutical dosage forms to eliminate the use of organic solvents during conventional liquid coating technologies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, the tribo-electrostatic separation (TES) of proteo-lignocellulosic biomass residues such as oilseed meals showed promise for sustainable classification of their ingredients with retained techno-functionalities. The main objectives were to assess the TES process as a water-, chemical-, and waste-free separation approach to fractionate proteo-lignocellulosic biomass residues, including soybean meals, into protein and dietary fiber while assessing the tribo-charging behavior of soy protein and dietary fiber particles at different particle dosing rates using different tribo-charger tube lengths and materials of PVC, nylon, PTFE, and copper. Our results revealed that the specific charges (nC/g) acquired by protein particles were highest at lower dosing rates with long tribo-charger tubes, indicating that particle-wall collisions contribute more to charge acquisition in diluted flows, while particle-particle collisions were more significant in concentrated flows.

Following the assessment of the charging behavior of soy protein particles, we have performed the TES of model binary and tertiary mixtures of protein-lignin, protein-cellulose, and protein-lignin-cellulose at concentrated dosing rates. Our results revealed that the protein enrichment levels were relatively similar regardless of the tribo-charger material used, indicating that particle-particle interactions play a significant role in the enrichment of soy protein. We discovered that higher levels of soy protein enrichment occur at lower protein concentrations in all model binary and tertiary mixtures. Additionally, we investigated the effects of laminar and turbulent airflow rates and different plate voltages during the TES of soybean meals. Our findings indicated the optimal conditions of laminar airflow and a high plate voltage. This combination resulted in the highest yields of protein and fiber particles, achieving separation efficiencies of 66.5% for protein and 25.1% for dietary fiber.

This project served as a training ground for three graduate students and four minority undergrads in Chemical Engineering at Howard University. All the undergraduate students who participated in the project earned their Bachelor of Science in Chemical Engineering, and one joined the PhD program at Ohio State University and the other a PhD program at Stanford University. The project also successfully contributed to the professional development of those undergraduate students who entered the STEM workforce. Participation in this research project allowed one female student to complete her Master of Science in Chemical Engineering successfully; she also received the prestigious Women in Chemical Engineering (WIC) travel award during the 2021 AIChE annual meeting before joining Georgia Tech University graduate school for PhD program. The project outcomes were disseminated to Howard University and broader scientific communities through a master thesis, a book chapter, journal manuscripts, and presentations given by the PI and student participants at national conferences.

In summary, this project resulted in the concurrent recovery of dietary fiber and protein from soybean meal at its native state while enabling food companies to capture market opportunities for healthier soy protein with superior bio-functionalities and no chemical residues through a dry and waste-free approach. It fundamentally resulted in understanding how the particle-particle and particle-wall collisions could affect the chargeability and separation of protein particles during the TES of proteo-lignocellulose particles.
